docs.title: Introduction
docs.text:
Welcome to the POLARIIS+ Documentation

Want to contribute to this documentation?

Start by exploring the guide on writing documentation. After making your updates, commit them, and the system will automatically build and deploy the changes to the public website.

docs.title: How this documentation is published
docs.text:
Searching how to publish this documentation ?

Once you push your changes to the main branch, the entire process is automated. Simply commit your updates, and the system will handle the rest seamlessly.

This documentation is publicly accessible, while its source remains private.

This page explains how and why the documentation is published this way, and documents the architectural choices behind it.

docs.title: Context and constraints
docs.text:
We want to:

  • Keep the documentation source private
  • Publish the documentation publicly
  • Avoid any dependency on a personal GitHub account
  • Host everything on GitHub Pages
  • Protect the content behind a password, even though it is publicly hosted

At the same time, GitHub imposes an important constraint:

GitHub Pages on the Free plan can only serve content from public repositories.

This means a private repository cannot directly publish to GitHub Pages.

docs.title: High-level architecture
docs.text:
To satisfy these constraints, we split responsibilities across two repositories:

  • A private monorepo containing:
  • MkDocs source files
  • Build configuration
  • Encryption configuration

  • CI/CD workflow

  • A public hosting repository containing:

  • Only the encrypted static output
  • No documentation source
  • No build configuration

The public repository exists only to serve GitHub Pages.

docs.title: Repositories involved
docs.text:
• Private source repository https://github.com/polariis-plus/polariis-plus-monorepo

  • Public hosting repository (GitHub Pages) https://github.com/polariis-plus/polariis-plus-documentation

  • Published website https://polariis-plus.github.io/polariis-plus-documentation/

docs.title: Documentation build and encryption
docs.text:
The documentation is built using MkDocs and then encrypted using Staticrypt.

Staticrypt performs client-side encryption of the generated static site and injects a password prompt into the final HTML. The result is a set of static files that can safely be hosted on any static hosting provider.

Important characteristics of this approach:

  • The encrypted site can be served as plain static files
  • No server-side logic or authentication is required
  • The password is never stored in the public repository

This provides a lightweight protection layer suitable for internal or semi-private documentation.

docs.title: Publishing from private to public
docs.text:
Because the source repository is private and the hosting repository is public, the deployment process must:

  • Build and encrypt the site inside the private repository
  • Publish only the encrypted output to the public repository
  • Authenticate securely across repositories

No source files are ever copied to the public repository.

docs.title: Authentication model
docs.text:
Publishing to the public repository is done using an organization-owned GitHub App, not a Personal Access Token.

The GitHub App:

  • Is owned by the organization, not a person
  • Is installed only on the public hosting repository
  • Has minimal permissions (contents: write)
  • Issues short-lived tokens used during deployment

GitHub App used: - docs-pages-publisher - Managed at: https://github.com/organizations/polariis-plus/settings/apps/docs-pages-publisher

This ensures the deployment process:

  • Continues to work even if contributors leave the organization
  • Follows GitHub’s recommended security model
  • Avoids long-lived, person-bound credentials

docs.title: GitHub Pages hosting
docs.text:
The public repository is configured to serve GitHub Pages from a dedicated branch containing the encrypted site.

As a result:

  • GitHub Pages sees a normal public static site
  • Visitors are prompted for a password before accessing content
  • The documentation source remains private at all times

docs.title: Security considerations
docs.text:
This setup provides content obfuscation and access friction, not strong access control.

  • Anyone with the password can access the content
  • Encrypted files are publicly downloadable
  • This is appropriate for:
  • internal documentation
  • partner documentation
  • non-sensitive technical material

It is not intended for secrets or regulated data.

docs.title: Writing documentation with MkDocs & Material
docs.text:
This documentation is built with MkDocs and the Material for MkDocs theme.

The goal is to make documentation: - easy to write - easy to review - easy to keep up to date

This page introduces the basics and provides concrete examples you can reuse when adding or updating documentation.

docs.title: What is MkDocs?
docs.text:
MkDocs is a static documentation generator:

  • Documentation is written in Markdown
  • Pages are converted into a static website
  • Navigation is defined explicitly
  • No framework or frontend knowledge required

If you can write Markdown, you can write documentation.

docs.title: What is Material for MkDocs?
docs.text:
Material for MkDocs is a theme that adds:

  • Clean, modern UI
  • Built-in search
  • Responsive layout
  • Syntax highlighting
  • Callouts, tabs, diagrams, and more

It allows us to keep documentation simple, while still being pleasant and powerful.

docs.title: Where documentation lives
docs.text:
Documentation files live in the repository under:

projects/docs/pages/

Each Markdown file corresponds to one page in the site.

Example:

projects/docs/pages/
├────────────────── index.md
├────────────────── publishing-docs.md
└────────────────── writing-docs.md

Navigation and ordering are controlled in projects/docs/mkdocs.yml.

Help text is a description read by screen readers to assist visually impaired users in understanding the content of an image or element.

docs.title: POLARIIS+: Overview
docs.text:
POLARIIS+ is a collaborative, open, and evolutive life cycle database of lifestyles in Canada. Its mission is to provide high‑quality, transparent, and regionalized life cycle inventory (LCI) and impact assessment (LCIA) data to support decision‑making toward more sustainable lifestyles at the individual, organizational, and governmental levels.

POLARIIS+ is developed jointly by researchers and partners across Canada, with the goal of democratizing access to environmental footprint information while ensuring methodological rigor, interoperability, and future‑proof design.

docs.title: Why POLARIIS+?
docs.text:
Traditional LCA databases often focus on production-based inventories. However, to address the environmental footprint of households, public services, and societal trends, a consumption‑based approach is essential. This perspective evaluates the impacts of what is consumed in a territory, including imported goods and services.

Canada currently lacks:

  • Regionalized and lifestyle‑oriented LCA data
  • Fine‑granularity datasets reflecting everyday consumption
  • Parametric, flexible datasets enabling scenario and sensitivity analysis
  • Open, transparent datasets
  • Tools that are interoperable, machine‑readable to easy to update as new knowledge emerges and structure suitable for automation, AI, and digital tools and
  • A collaborative ecosystem for contributions, updates, and versioning

POLARIIS+ is designed to fill these gaps.

docs.title: Project Objectives
docs.text:
POLARIIS+ aims to structure and disseminate LCI and footprint data to:

  • Support evidence‑based decisions for citizens, companies, NGOs, and governments
  • Enable modeling of behaviour‑based scenarios
  • Provide a robust basis for public policies, organizational sustainability strategies, and educational initiatives
  • Empower citizens and professionals with open, accurate, and reproducible knowledge
  • Foster large‑scale collaborations and co‑creation of data across Canada

The platform will ultimately offer a versatile, modular, parametrized, and open framework capable of evolving with time, data contributions, and new scientific advances.

docs.title: Holistic Coverage
docs.text:
• Full life cycles including production and consumption
  • Multisectoral: food, transport, housing, digital services, health and personal care, culture, clothing, and more

docs.title: Regionalization
docs.text:
• Canada-wide
  • Provincial granularity (Québec, other provinces)
  • Distinction between domestic production and imports

docs.title: Versatility
docs.text:
• Multiple functional units and user profiles
  • Different levels of detail (items → recipes → meals → diets)
  • Multivariate contribution analysis

docs.title: Flexibility
docs.text:
• Parameterized datasets
  • Modular structure enabling the addition, removal, or adjustment of processes
  • Ontology-based modelling
  • Generic, reusable templates
  • Consistent parameter inheritance

docs.title: Collaboration & Interoperability
docs.text:
• Designed for data contributors, users, and partners
  • Compatible with external LCI databases and LCA software
  • API-based integration and machine-readable formats
  • Open access to foster participation and transparency

docs.title: Evolutiveness
docs.text:
• Version control
  • Branching capabilities for alternative modelling options
  • Capacity to incorporate new datasets over time

docs.title: Scope and System Boundaries
docs.text:
POLARIIS+ connects detailed consumption modelling (behaviours, choices, profiles) with production processes using a structured, harmonized process tree. Examples include:

  • For food: items → recipes → meals → diets, with detailed agricultural production, processing, packaging, transport, distribution, and end‑of‑life.
  • For transport: mobility behaviours, vehicle technologies, energy sources, and infrastructure.
  • For housing: buildings, energy use, materials.

The database interfaces with background LCI databases to complete full life cycle modelling.

docs.title: Multi-Dimensional Coverage
docs.text:
• Consumption sectors: transport, housing, food, travel, culture, clothing, health, finance, education, communication, public services, etc.
  • Environmental indicators: based on IMPACT World+ covering carbon footprint, water footprint, mineral and fossil resource use, human health, ecosystem quality
  • User needs and profiles: lifestyles, activity patterns, and behavioural assumptions relevant to Canadians

POLARIIS+ aims to represent the annual needs of Canadians through a comprehensive consumption-based lens.

docs.title: Methodology and Tools
docs.text:
Dataset creation follows a structured methodology:

  1. Definition of functional units relevant to lifestyles
  2. Ontologies for objects, processes, and impacts
  3. Harmonized process trees across sectors
  4. Prioritization of high-impact or high‑volume items
  5. Parameter development and equations
  6. Structured data collection templates
  7. Activity instantiation with validation and rules
  8. Dissemination through a web platform, APIs, documentation, and scientific outputs

This approach ensures consistency, transparency, and reproducibility.

docs.title: Current Progress
docs.text:
The following sectors are under active development:

  • Food: existing beta version
  • Transport
  • Housing existing beta version
  • Digital services
  • Hygiene and personal care existing beta version

Work is ongoing to expand sectoral coverage, incorporate new contributors, and refine licensing models.

docs.title: Collaboration and Governance
docs.text:
POLARIIS+ is built as a collaborative ecosystem involving:

  • Data contributors (experts, institutions, researchers, public agencies)
  • Direct and indirect users (LCA practitioners, analysts, policymakers, educators)
  • Financial contributors
  • A development team responsible for the LCI database and the footprint database structures, tools, and integration

Strong partnerships help ensure data quality, representativeness, and long-term viability.

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
Upcoming priorities include:

  • Increasing the number and scope of datasets
  • Expanding collaborations and partnerships
  • Clarifying licensing with background databases
  • Improving tools for users and contributors
  • Strengthening the API ecosystem and documentation

docs.title: Glossary
docs.text: Working Draft — This glossary defines the core concepts used to model the database architecture, ontology, and algorithms. It is a living document intended to evolve as concepts are refined.

docs.title: 1. Scope and Modeling Layers
docs.text:
The model distinguishes between two main layers:

  • Object-of-study layer: describes what is studied (dimensions, modalities, profiles, taxonomies).
  • LCA process layer: describes how transformations are modeled (activities, flows, parameters).

This glossary is organized to follow a logical reading order, starting from the object of study and progressively introducing activities, flows, and calculations.

docs.title: 2. Dimension
docs.text:
A dimension is an analytical axis describing a relevant way of differentiating objects of study. A dimension defines what can vary when describing an object of study in POLARIIS+.

Each dimension:

  • Belongs to exactly one space
  • Contains a finite set of modalities
  • Can be fundamental (e.g. location, temporality)

Examples (POLARIIS+):

  • Food product (e.g. tomato, aubergine, salmon)
  • Food production mode (e.g. organic, conventional, greenhouse)
  • Vehicle class (e.g. passenger car, light-duty truck)
  • Powertrain (e.g. ICE, BEV, PHEV)
  • Battery type (e.g. Li-ion NMC, LFP)
  • Location (e.g. Quebec, Canada, GLO)

docs.title: 3. Modality
docs.text:
A modality is a concrete value of a dimension. It represents how a dimension is specified.

Modalities:

  • Can appear in profiles or taxonomies
  • Can carry properties even if they are never used in a profile

Examples (POLARIIS+):

  • Aubergine is a modality of the Food product dimension
  • Organic is a modality of the Food production mode dimension
  • Battery electric vehicle is a modality of the Powertrain dimension
  • LFP is a modality of the Battery type dimension
  • Quebec is a modality of the Location dimension

docs.title: 4. Object-of-Study Taxonomies
docs.text:
In the object-of-study ontology, a taxonomy is a hierarchical organization of modalities belonging to a single dimension into taxonomic levels.

A taxonomy answers the question: at which level of granularity do we want to describe or analyse objects of study?

Characteristics:

  • Applies to one dimension only
  • Organised in levels of abstraction (no tiers, no tags)
  • Several alternative taxonomies may coexist for the same dimension

Main uses:

  • Contribution analyses at different levels of aggregation
  • Inheritance of properties and property values between modalities

Example — Food product (POLARIIS+):

Taxonomy A:

Level Value Level 1 Food Level 2 Vegetable Level 3 Aubergine

Taxonomy B (alternative for the same dimension):

Level Value Level 1 Food Level 2 Fresh produce Level 3 Aubergine

docs.title: 5. Profile
docs.text:
A profile is a partial combination of modalities across dimensions. It represents a state of specification of an object of study in POLARIIS+.

A profile describes an open space of possibilities: some dimensions may be specified, others not.

Note on fundamental dimensions: A profile must always include fundamental dimensions, notably location and temporality, even if their values are generic (e.g. GLO, undefined).

Example (POLARIIS+):

A food-related profile may combine:

  • Food product = Aubergine
  • Production mode = Greenhouse
  • Location = Quebec
  • Temporality = 2020–2025

docs.title: 5.1 Profile Specification Levels
docs.text:
Profiles exist at three levels of specification:

Level Notation Description Non-specified Dim × Dim × Dim × … No modality is specified. The profile represents a very large space of possibilities. Semi-specified Dim × Dim × Mod × … At least one modality is specified, but not all. E.g. {Location: Quebec} or {Food product: Aubergine} Fully specified Mod × Mod × Mod × … A fully specified profile becomes an object of study.

docs.title: 6. Object of Study
docs.text:
An object of study is a fully specified profile: all relevant dimensions have an assigned modality.

It is the central unit of calculation in POLARIIS+.

An object of study is not the real-world object, but a parametric representation that allows LCA calculations.

Example (POLARIIS+):

{Food product: Aubergine, Production mode: Greenhouse, Location: Quebec, Temporality: 2020–2025}

Only objects of study can be used to instantiate activities.

docs.title: 7. Implicit Profile Sets
docs.text:
(formerly: profile systems)

Any non-specified or semi-specified profile implicitly represents a set of fully specified profiles. This implicit set corresponds to what was previously called a profile system.

Key idea:

  • The model reasons on profiles
  • Sets of profiles are implicit, not first-class objects

These implicit sets:

  • Hide many potential objects of study
  • Are used to represent incomplete inputs or outputs
  • Allow inheritance and value imputation

docs.title: 8. Property
docs.text:
A property is a quantitative or qualitative attribute associated with all profiles of a given profile system.

Properties:

  • May be inherited across profile systems
  • Can be computed, imputed, or sourced from data
  • Feed parameters in generic activities

docs.title: 9. Inheritance Tree
docs.text:
The inheritance tree is a conceptual structure that links profiles (and implicit profile sets) according to their level of specification.

It organizes how information can be shared between:

  • Non-specified profiles
  • Semi-specified profiles
  • Fully specified profiles (objects of study)

This tree supports value propagation (imputation), but the propagation itself is not a standalone concept: it is a consequence of the linking structure.

Role:

  • Enables reuse of data defined at higher or lower levels of specification
  • Avoids duplicating values for each object of study

docs.title: 10.1 Generic Activity
docs.text:
A generic activity represents a non-instantiated LCA process.

It defines:

  • A recurring structure of inputs and outputs
  • Parametric equations
  • The expected types of providers

It does not depend on any specific object of study.

Generic activities exist primarily to facilitate the work of modelers, avoid repeatedly rebuilding similar processes, and define reusable structural patterns. They act as templates for instantiation.

Examples (POLARIIS+):

  • Cook 1 kg of food (raw food → cooked food + energy)
  • Manufacture a food product
  • Construct an electric vehicle
  • Transport food by truck

docs.title: 10.2 Instantiated Activity
docs.text:
An instantiated activity results from:

generic activity × object of study

It has:

  • Fully evaluated numerical values
  • Quantified flows
  • Determined providers

This is the activity that enters the final LCA inventory.

docs.title: 10. Configuration
docs.text:
A configuration is a fully specified profile belonging to a configuration system.

It represents a concrete instantiation context for a generic activity.

docs.title: 11. Activity
docs.text:
An activity represents a transformation process. It connects inputs to outputs using equations and parameters.

Activities exist in two forms:

  • Generic activities — structural, non-instantiated
  • Instantiated activities — fully calculated, inventory-ready

docs.title: 11.1 Activity Action
docs.text:
The action of an activity characterizes the role played by the activity in the process chain (e.g. manufacturing, transport, use, end-of-life).

The activity action is essential for automatic process-tree construction.

When selecting a provider for an input, the algorithm does not rely only on the profile produced, because multiple activities may produce the same profile.

Example (POLARIIS+):

  • Food manufacturing produces the profile "tomato"
  • Food transportation also produces the profile "tomato"

If the input requires a provider with the action manufacturing, this information guides the algorithm toward the correct provider.

Rule: The proxy_action must always be explicitly provided. It is mandatory and cannot be inferred by the algorithm.

docs.title: 12. Activities and Subflows
docs.text:
Generic activities can be refined through subflows:

  • To specialize inputs or outputs
  • To replace generic energy carriers (e.g. energy → electricity)
  • To instantiate only part of the structure

When starting from scratch, a generic activity must be created first.

docs.title: 13. Provider
docs.text:
A provider is the activity that supplies an input to another activity.

Conceptually:

  • A generic input refers to a system of profiles
  • Its provider is therefore a system of activities

At instantiation time, one concrete provider activity is selected or forced.

Rules:

  • Provider selection depends on activity action × profile
  • Without an algorithm, providers must be forced explicitly

docs.title: 14. Flow
docs.text: A flow is a declarative connection between activities.

docs.title: 14.1 Incomplete Flow
docs.text:
An incomplete flow:

  • Originates from a generic or partially instantiated activity
  • Has no identified provider
  • Is associated with a non-specified or semi-specified profile

It represents an open request for a provider.

docs.title: 14.2 Complete Flow
docs.text:
A complete flow is determined by:

  • A fully specified object of study
  • One origin activity (instantiated)
  • One destination activity (instantiated)

A complete flow:

  • Has no intrinsic location, value, or temporality
  • Acts as a channel between activities
  • Derives its effective location from the connected activities

Flows are purely declarative and are never used directly in algorithms.

docs.title: 15. Location and Temporality
docs.text:
Location and temporality are fundamental dimensions.

Rules:

  • Every profile must define them
  • Activities may define their own
  • Flow location is a consequence of activities, not a property of the flow

docs.title: 16. Foreground vs Background
docs.text: Layer Description Foreground Processes modeled and controlled within the database ontology Background External processes (e.g. ecoinvent, agribalyse)

docs.title: 17. Object of Study Ontology
docs.text: Ontology describing dimensions, modalities, profiles, taxonomies, and properties.

docs.title: 18. LCA Ontology
docs.text: Ontology describing activities, flows, functional units, parameters, equations, and LCA taxonomies.

docs.title: 19. LCA Taxonomy (Activities)
docs.text:
In the LCA ontology, a taxonomy organizes activities in order to support contribution analyses on process trees.

A single LCA taxonomy is composed of multiple levels, each level representing an analytical axis. These levels are not independent taxonomies but parts of the same taxonomy.

Conceptual parallel with object-of-study taxonomies:

LCA taxonomy Object-of-study taxonomy Level Dimension (analytical axis) Tier Taxonomic level (degree of granularity) Stage Modality

Structure of one LCA taxonomy:

  • The taxonomy contains several levels (e.g. life cycle phase, digital layer)
  • Each level is structured into tiers (macro → micro)
  • Each tier contains several stages

Within a same taxonomy, stages of the lowest tier of one level may be linked to stages of the highest tier of another level, allowing coherent navigation and aggregation across levels.

General rules:

  • An activity may belong to multiple LCA taxonomies
  • Within a given taxonomy, an activity may have at most one stage per level

Example — Digital LCA taxonomy (POLARIIS+):

Level 1 — Life cycle phase:

Tier Stages Tier 1 Infrastructure manufacturing, Electronics manufacturing Tier 2 Semiconductor manufacturing, PCB manufacturing Tier 3 Wafer production, Chip fabrication, Photolithography

Level 2 — Digital layers:

Tier Stages Tier 1 User terminal, Network access Tier 2 Servers, Network equipment, Terminals Tier 3 CPU, GPU, Memory, Optical cables

Cross-level links (examples):

  • Stage chip fabrication → linked to stage CPU
  • Stage semiconductor manufacturing → linked to stage component layer

These links allow contribution analyses that combine life cycle logic with system architecture granularity.

docs.title: 19. Bridge Between Ontologies
docs.text: The bridge connects the object-of-study ontology to the LCA ontology via property values used in activity instantiation.

docs.title: 20. Roles and Governance
docs.text:
Role Responsibility Ontology builders Define generic activities and structures Inventory experts Instantiate detailed processes

Good governance ensures consistency, traceability, and reuse.

docs.title: 21. Parameter
docs.text:
A parameter is a value or variable used in the equations of generic activities.

Parameters are a core modeling concept: they encode physical, technical, or methodological relationships.

Parameters may be:

  • Independent of profiles
  • Dependent on profiles (via properties)
  • Dependent on activities
  • Dependent on profile × activity combinations

Parameters are evaluated at instantiation time.

docs.title: Generic parameter (profile- and activity-independent)
docs.text:
A constant valid in all contexts.

Example: Gravitational acceleration (9.81 m·s⁻²)

docs.title: Profile-dependent parameter
docs.text:
A parameter whose value depends on the object of study.

Example: Water content of aubergine (depends on the Food product profile)

docs.title: Activity-dependent parameter
docs.text:
A parameter specific to a transformation process, regardless of the object of study.

Example: Efficiency of an industrial electric oven used in a cooking activity

docs.title: Profile × activity–dependent parameter
docs.text:
A parameter that depends jointly on the object of study and on characteristics of the activity.

  • The profile captures what is transformed (e.g. the specific food item)
  • The activity captures how it is transformed (e.g. cooking technology, process conditions)

Example: Cooking energy required for 1 kg of food as a function of the specific food item (e.g. aubergine, via its water content) and the chosen cooking technology (e.g. electric oven, gas stove)
